title: 110_s2006
content: The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" may provide disaster assistance for power transmission and distribution facilities. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act now includes a definition for private or investor-owned power facilities, which are privately-owned transmission or distribution facilities providing electric or natural gas service to retail customers. This definition also covers leased facilities. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act now includes conditions for contributions to private or investor-owned power facilities that are damaged. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act now includes conditions for providing assistance to private or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster for repair and associated expenses. The term "previous major disaster" is defined as a major disaster that occurred before the current disaster and was declared within 10 years. Assistance to private or investor-owned power facilities is conditioned on the occurrence of a previous major disaster. Federal assistance is available under this subsection if the cost of repairing, restoring, or replacing private or investor-owned power facilities damaged in a previous major disaster exceeded $2,500 for each retail customer. The total costs of repair, restoration, or replacement of private or investor-owned power facilities must exceed $500,000,000 for federal assistance to be available. The previous major disaster must have caused damages exceeding $500,000,000 and affected at least 25% of the population in each geographic area where the power facility is located. A person owning a power facility can apply for funds in such cases. A person owning a private or investor-owned power facility that meets specific requirements can apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of a major disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards repair costs. The owner of a private or investor-owned power facility can receive Federal assistance for repair costs if they contribute $10,000,000 towards the total expenses. Federal assistance is limited to costs exceeding $10,000,000 directly incurred by the owner. The President must approve or disapprove assistance applications within 30 days. Costs from previous disasters in a 12-month period will be aggregated for determining eligibility. The Federal Share under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities. Additionally, a new provision for Large In-Lieu Contributions is added to the Act. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities. A new provision for Large In-Lieu Contributions is added, allowing owners to receive a contribution instead of repairing or replacing the facility. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act now includes private or investor-owned power facilities. Owners can receive a contribution equal to 75% of the Federal estimate for repairing or replacing the facility, under specific conditions. The funds can be used to repair, restore, or expand other power facilities owned by the person. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act now covers private or investor-owned power facilities. Owners can receive 75% of the Federal estimate for repairs or replacements. The funds can be used for repairing, restoring, or expanding other power facilities owned by the person. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act now includes private or investor-owned power facilities as eligible for assistance. Owners can receive 75% of the Federal estimate for repairs or replacements, which can be used for repairing, restoring, or expanding other power facilities owned by the person. The Secretary of Homeland Security must create regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment to implement the Act and its amendments. The Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, with Section 3 taking effect immediately.
